Promoting effect of alkaline earth metals on Ni/CeO2 catalysts for ammonia decomposition reaction Zhen Zhang Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a Minghui Yu Validation Methodology Conceptualization a Meiqing Shen Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b Wei Li Writing – review & editing Validation Software Conceptualization b Gurong Shen Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization c ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 China aSchool of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China b National Rare Earth Catalysis Research Institute, Dongying 257000, China National Rare Earth Catalysis Research Institute Dongying 257000 China bNational Rare Earth Catalysis Research Institute, Dongying 257000, China c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 China cSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Ni-based catalysts, as non-noble metal alternatives, are widely regarded for their potential in ammonia decomposition for hydrogen production. However, their performance at low temperatures is suboptimal, necessitating the addition of promoters and a clear understanding of their mechanisms to enhance catalytic activity. In this study, we have successfully improved the low-temperature ammonia decomposition performance of Ni/CeO2 by incorporating alkaline earth metals and conducted a comprehensive analysis of the underlying structural and electronic effects. The findings reveal that alkaline earth metals can enhance the basicity of the catalyst and increase electron density around the active metal sites, thereby facilitating the rate-determining step of recombination and desorption of N atom. Moreover, the presence of alkaline earth metals disrupts hydrogen adsorption stability on the catalysts, effectively mitigating the impact of hydrogen inhibition. Based on systematic kinetic experiments, a kinetic model was developed that accurately captures the hydrogen inhibition effect for Ni/CeO2 catalysts. The insights into the promotional mechanisms of alkaline earth metals offer theoretical guidance for the development of highly active and cost-effective catalysts for ammonia decomposition. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia decomposition Alkaline earth metal Hydrogen inhibition Kinetic model Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Ammonia, as an excellent hydrogen carrier, has several advantages [1–3]: (1) ammonia has a high hydrogen content of about 17.7 wt%, and liquid ammonia exhibits a high volumetric energy density of 12.9 MJ·L-1 [4–6]; (2) ammonia, as a carbon-free compound, can be burned directly; (3) Compared to the very low liquefaction temperature (-253 °C) of hydrogen, ammonia is easily liquefied at -33 °C [7], making it less expensive to store and transport than hydrogen [8]; (4) Ammonia is safe as a fuel with its explosion limit (15 %–28 %) much higher than that of hydrogen, and once ammonia leaks, the pungent odor can be detected quickly. Hence ammonia can be widely used in the transportation field, such as automobiles, airplanes, ships etc [9]. In addition, catalytic technology can be used to efficiently decompose ammonia to hydrogen when needed [10–12]. Ammonia decomposition reaction to generate nitrogen and hydrogen is endothermic (Eq. (1)), (1) 2 N H 3 = N 2 + 3 H 2 Δ H = 92 KJ · mo l − 1 Efficient and inexpensive hydrogen production from ammonia decomposition technology requires low-cost, highly active and stable catalysts. Nowadays, Ni-based catalysts have received much attention for their good catalytic activity and economic benefits, but their low-temperature performance needs to be improved [13]. However, selecting the appropriate supports and promoters can effectively enhance the activity of the catalyst. Deng [14] showed Ni/Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 catalysts to be more active than Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Al2O3, and they attributed it to the promoting effect of Ce, the doping of Zr4+ cations, and interactions between Ni and the support. Zhang et al. [15] used La to modify Ni/Al2O3, and found that La as a promoter could reduce the particle size of Ni and decrease the stability of the reaction intermediates in the active site, and the inhibitory effect of H2 was also mentioned. Increasing the alkalinity of the supports have become one of the important strategies to enhance the activity of ammonia decomposition catalysts. For ammonia decomposition reaction, the recombination of N atom and desorption of N2 are generally regarded as the rate-determining steps [16–18]. Basic promoters function as electron donors, transferring electrons to metal centers, which weakens the metal-nitrogen bond and aids in the desorption of nitrogen [19–22]. Guo [23] synthesized the La0.5Sr0.5NiO3-δ-600H2 catalyst by incorporating SrO, which served dual roles as support and promoter, and this catalyst demonstrated an exceptional conversion of ammonia decomposition. However, the impact of “hydrogen inhibition” caused by the competitive adsorption of NH3 and H2 on active sites during ammonia decomposition cannot be overlooked. Previous reports have suggested that the strong basic property of catalysts can mitigate the inhibitory effect of H2 on ammonia decomposition, but systematic evidence is generally lacking. Recently, ammonia decomposition catalysts prepared with single alkaline earth metals as promoters (Ni/MgO-La2O3 [24], Ni/CaZrO3 [25], SrO-Ni/Y2O3 [26], Co-Ba/Y2O3 [27]) have been frequently reported. Alkaline earth metals M (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba), while belonging to the same group and sharing similar physical and chemical characteristics, also exhibit regular differences in ionic radii and electronegativity. These developments and theories inspire us to select the same carrier for a systematic and in-depth exploration of the mechanism by which alkaline earth metals enhance the catalytic activity of ammonia decomposition. In this work, we synthesized CeO2 support modified with alkaline earth metals M (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba) via citric acid complexation method, and assessed their catalytic activities for ammonia decomposition following the loading of Ni. The incorporation of alkaline earth metals was found to markedly enhance the catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition, and increase the rate of hydrogen formation. We focus on analyzing the mechanism of alkaline earth metal promotion of catalytic activity from the perspectives of catalyst structural properties and electronic effects. The addition of alkaline earth metals can increase the electronic density around the active metal sites, thereby facilitating the slow kinetic step of associative desorption of N atoms. Kinetic studies are crucial for a deeper understanding of the mechanisms involved in ammonia decomposition reaction, which in turn informs the design of more efficient catalysts. To this end, we conducted comprehensive kinetic experiments to explore the mitigation of hydrogen inhibition by alkaline earth metals after eliminating both internal and external diffusion. Utilizing the kinetic parameters derived from these experiments, we developed a Ni/CeO2 kinetic model that accurately captures and validates the hydrogen inhibition effect during the ammonia decomposition reaction. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation Alkaline earth metal M (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba) modified CeO2 were synthesized by the citric acid complexation method. The CeO2 was obtained by dissolving 17.37 g of Ce(NO)3·6H2O (Aladdin) and 11.58 g of citric acid (Aladdin) in 50 mL of deionized water, stirring at 80 °C for 3 h, drying in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h, followed by calcining at 600 °C for 5 h in a muffle furnace. The same procedure was used to prepare alkaline earth metals (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba) modified CeO2 supports, using the alkaline earth metal to Ce molar ratio of M2+: Ce3+ = 2: 8. The Ni/M0.2Ce0.8Ox catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method. 1.01 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in a certain amount of deionized water at room temperature, and then mixed with 2 g of the supports. The sample was dried at 80 °C for 3 h and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h. 2.2 Catalytic testing The ammonia decomposition experiments were carried out in a quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 13 mm [28]. Before the test, 0.1 g of catalyst was mixed with 0.9 g of quartz sand, and 100 mL·min-1 of 10 % H2/N2 was passed through the reactor at 550 °C for 2 h. The reactor was purged and cooled down to 350 °C in Ar, and then pure NH3 was passed through the reactor at 15 mL·min-1, and the reaction temperature was varied from 350 °C to 650 °C with an interval of 25 °C. The conversion was measured at steady state after 20 min. Product on-line analysis was performed using a Fourier infrared gas analyzer (MKS MultiGas 2030). The catalytic activity was compared by both conversion as in Eq. (2) and rate of hydrogen production as in Eq. (3), where L (NH3, inlet) stands for inlet NH3 flow rate. (2) X N H 3 % = C ( N H 3 , i n l e t ) − C ( N H 3 , o u t l e t ) C ( N H 3 , i n l e t ) * 100 % (3) H 2 form ation rate ( mmol · g − 1 · min − 1 ) = L ( N H 3 , inlet ) * X N H 3 ( % ) * 1.5 V m * m cat 2.3 Characterization The specific surface areas and pore volumes of the samples were assessed by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, which were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP physisorption instrument at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (-196 °C). Prior to the measurements, the samples were subjected to degassing under vacuum at 300 °C for a duration of 2 h. The specific surface areas were determined employing the Bruner-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, while the pore volumes were derived using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Elemental analysis of the samples was carried out by Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES, Thermal Fisher). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a diffractometer (Haoyuan DX-2700BH) employing Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The data collection spanned from 20 to 90° with a step increment of 0.05°. The crystallite sizes were calculated using the Scherrer formula D = K λ β cos θ , where D represents the crystallite size in nanometers, λ is the wavelength in nanometers, β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the target diffraction peak, and θ is the peak position in degrees. STEM-Mapping images were acquired using a JEM-F200 transmission electron microscope. The powder was deposited onto a twin-grid mesh coated with a carbon film, which was first suspended in ethanol and then sonicated for 30 min. The twin-grid mesh support film not only prevents sample movement due to the magnetic field of the electron microscope, but also protects against contamination from magnetic samples, making it highly effective for the observation of magnetic material samples. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was carried out using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 0.1 g catalyst was reduced at 550 °C under a 10 % H2/N2 for 2 h. Subsequently, the catalyst was cooled to 50 °C under a He purge. The pretreated catalyst was then exposed to a CO2 flow for 1 h, followed by a 1 h He purge to remove the remaining CO2 gas. The desorption behavior of CO2 was recorded by TCD under pure He flow (30 mL·min-1) with a temperature ramp of 10 °C·min-1. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and desorption (TPD) with H2 were conducted on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 system. Approximately 0.1g sample was used for each test. Each catalyst in H2-TPR experiment was measured at 10 % H2/N2 (30 mL/min) from 40 °C to 900 °C with a constant heating rate of 10 °C·min-1, and H2 consumption was quantified by using Ag2O as a reference measured on the same system. Prior to the TPD measurements, each catalyst (0.1 g) was pre-reduced in situ at 550 °C under 10 % H2/N2. The reduced sample was cooled in situ to 30 °C and adsorbed for 1 h under a 10 % H2/Ar flow, after which it was purged with pure Ar to achieve a stable baseline. The desorption curve was subsequently recorded under pure Ar flow (30 mL·min-1) with a temperature ramp of 10 °C·min-1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed using a Thermo K-ALPHA system fitted with an Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). Wide-scan spectra were acquired with a step increment of 1.0 eV. The Ni 2p and Ce 3d regions were scanned within the energy ranges of 850–865 and 875–925 eV, respectively, with a step size of 0.1 eV. Binding energies (BE) were referenced to the adventitious carbon peak (C 1s BE at 284.8 eV). Throughout the measurements, the pressure in the analysis chamber was kept at 5 × 10⁻⁷ Pa. 2.4 Kinetic model The ammonia decomposition kinetics model is established using GT-POWER, a solver within the GT-SUITE engine performance simulation software developed by Gamma Technologies. The flow components mainly include the gas inlet, inlet conical channel, catalytic reactor, outlet conical channel, and outlet environment. The CatalystBrick component is used to define the geometric dimensions, channel shape, and discrete length of the catalyst carrier. As a flow component, it requires axial discretization to ensure accuracy, and the composition materials and thermodynamic parameters of the catalyst support must also be defined. After the physical model of the catalyst is established, based on this physical model, the ammonia decomposition catalytic reaction mechanism is added through the SurfaceReactions module, including the corresponding concentration reaction equations and inhibition term equations. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance: activity and stability The catalytic activity of both Ni/CeO2 and Ni/M0.2Ce0.8Ox samples for ammonia decomposition was evaluated at a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 9000 mL·gcat -1·h-1. The corresponding light-off curves are presented in Fig. 1 (a) and the rates of H2 formation at 475 °C are shown in Fig. 1(b). The order of the performance is as follows: Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Ca0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Mg0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/CeO2, with the rate of H2 formation exhibiting a similar trend. Notably, at 475 °C, the conversion rate for Ni/CeO2 is a mere 12 %, whereas Ba doping significantly enhances the catalytic activity of Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox, boosting the conversion rate to approximately 32 %. Ni/CeO2 catalyst requires a temperature of 550 °C to achieve a 50 % conversion in ammonia decomposition. In contrast, catalysts modified with alkaline earth metals can substantially reduce the T50 value, enabling higher conversions at lower temperatures. These results indicate that the incorporation of alkaline earth metals can effectively improve the catalytic activity of ammonia decomposition. Fig. 1(c) depicts the 24 h stability tests conducted on catalysts Ni/CeO2 and the highest activity Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox. The Ni/CeO2 can maintain a stable ammonia decomposition conversion rate of 30 % at 525 °C. When the temperature was lowered to 475 °C and then returned to the original temperature of 525 °C, the catalyst's conversion rate rebounded to its initial level (30 %), indicating that Ni/CeO2 exhibits good durability and stability under temperature cycling. For catalyst Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox, no performance degradation was observed even after prolonged exposure to high temperatures of 550 °C, with the final ammonia decomposition conversion rate maintained at 84 %. These results validate that the synthesized alkaline earth metals modified Ni/CeO2 catalysts possesses outstanding thermal stability. 3.2 The catalysts properties Fig. 2 (a) and (b) show the XRD patterns of the catalysts after calcination and reduction, respectively. In the case of the calcined samples, the XRD patterns revealed, in addition to the characteristic peaks of CeO2, new peaks emerging at 2θ = 37.3° and 43.3°, which corresponding to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of NiO, respectively. For the reduced samples, diffraction peaks of metallic Ni were detected except for Ni/Mg0.2Ce0.8Ox. The absence of metallic nickel peaks in this particular sample suggests a strong interaction between nickel and MgO, potentially leading to the formation of MgNiO2 species [29]. These species are speculated to be resistant to reduction, thus preventing the formation of the nickel metal phase. The specific surface area and pore structure of the supports and catalysts were characterized using N2 adsorption-desorption analysis. Fig. S2(a) and (b) present the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the supports and catalysts, respectively. The isotherms are classified as type IV, and the hysteresis loops are of type H3, indicative of a mesoporous structure predominantly comprising lamellar arrangements within the aggregate morphology. Table 1 quantifies the active metal Ni loading, specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of the catalysts. Compared to the support CeO2 with a specific surface area of 33.5 m2·g-1, the specific surface areas of Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox (17.3 m2·g-1) and Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox (16.5 m2·g-1) showed a significant decrease. The phenomenon appears to be detrimental to the dispersion of the active metal Ni. However, it was observed that the performance of catalysts showed an improving trend in the ammonia decomposition reaction tests. STEM-mapping, facilitated by high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF-STEM) images of samples are shown in Fig. S4, the Ba element is distributed quite uniformly, indicating that the citric acid complexation method effectively forms metal-citrate chelates, which in turn ensures a uniform elemental distribution during the material synthesis process. In the case of supports with a reduced specific surface area due to the incorporation of alkaline earth metals, severe aggregation of Ni elements was observed, indicating that a decrease in surface area is detrimental to the dispersion of active metals. Nevertheless, this aggregation did not significantly impact the comparison of ammonia decomposition conversion, suggesting that other factors are more critical in the catalytic process. The acid-base property of the catalysts was elucidated through CO2-TPD analysis to probe the quantity and intensity of basic sites, as shown in Fig. 3 . The peaks between 70 °C–150 °C (α) and 150 °C–400 °C (β) correspond to the desorption of CO2 from weak and moderate basic sites on the catalyst, respectively. Whereas the peaks after 400 °C (γ) are indicative of CO2 desorption from ligand-oxygen species on the strong basic sites or decomposition of the carbonates [30]. The upward trend in the desorption peaks temperature of CO2 for the low temperature α peak indicates that the alkaline earth metals have increased the basic strength of the weak basic sites. For peaks of β, the Ni/Ca0.2Ce0.8Ox catalyst exhibits a higher CO2 desorption peak temperature compared to the Ni/Mg0.2Ce0.8Ox catalyst, indicating a stronger basicity, which is consistent with the properties of alkaline earth metals. The significant CO2 desorption observed for both catalysts is primarily attributed to the presence of alkaline earth metal oxides (MgO, CaO) [31,32]. Although these oxides provide a considerable number of basic sites, their basicity strength is considerably lower than that of the Ni/Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox and Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox catalysts. Additionally, in comparison with the Ni/Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox catalyst, the Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox catalyst exhibits similar basicity strength but a greater number of basic sites. Several researchers have proposed that oxygen vacancies can typically act as Lewis basic sites to adsorb CO2 [33]. The higher oxygen vacancy concentration of the Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox catalyst compared to the Ni/Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox catalyst, as quantitatively determined by XPS in Table 1, reasonably accounts for the differences between the two. Overall, these results demonstrated that both the basicity strength and the quantity of basic sites contribute positively to enhancing the catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition. The incorporation of alkaline earth metals effectively enhances the basicity [25,34,35]. This enhancement implies an increased electron-donating capacity, which weakens Ni-N bond and facilitate the re-combinative desorption of N* [36–38], while also mitigating the effect of the hydrogen inhibition phenomenon [39–41]. The H2 adsorption and desorption capacities were measured by H2-TPD, as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The hydrogen desorption peaks (α) observed between 80 °C and 200 °C are attributed to H2 adsorbed by dispersed Ni particles on the supports. Peaks (β) above 200 °C are associated with the desorption of H2 that is more strongly bound to the catalyst, potentially due to spillover from the support or desorption on Ni-O-M (where M represents Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba) sites [42]. The hydrogen adsorption and desorption on active sites influence the catalytic activity of reaction. Therefore, we propose that peak (α) directly reflects the influence of the adsorption and desorption behavior of active metal Ni0 with H2 on the establishment of equilibrium in ammonia decomposition reaction. The sequence of peak hydrogen desorption temperatures, Ni/CeO2 > Ni/Mg0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Ca0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox, between 80 °C and 200 °C is believed to correlate with the stability of hydrogen on the active sites. By comparing the integral area of peak (α), it indicated that the incorporation of alkaline earth metals tends to reduce the amount of hydrogen adsorbed on Ni. Overall, the decrease in both the desorption peak temperature and quantity of hydrogen on active sites indicates that the incorporation of alkaline earth metals can effectively mitigate the effects of hydrogen inhibition, thereby promoting the catalytic activity of ammonia decomposition [15,36,43]. The metal-support interaction and the reduction behavior were probed by the H2-TPR technique, and the results are shown in Fig. 4(b). In the case of the Ni/CeO2 sample, the peaks between 150 °C and 250 °C are ascribed to the reduction of oxygen species resulting from the incorporation of Ni2+ into the CeO2 lattice to form a solid solution. And the peaks between 250 °C and 450 °C correspond to the reduction of NiO that interact strongly with the supports [44]. The addition of alkaline earth metals was observed to increase the temperature of the reduction peak, with the disappearance of the reduction peak at 208 °C, indicating a stronger interaction between the NiO and the alkaline earth metal in the support. It has been reported that an enhancement in metal-support interaction is beneficial for improving the performance of ammonia decomposition catalysts, however, a stronger interaction is not always preferable. For instance, in the case of the Ni/Mg0.2Ce0.8Ox catalyst, only a negligible hydrogen consumption peak was observed, which is attributed to the formation of MgNiO2 due to the strong interaction between NiO and the support, making the active metal Ni0 more difficult to reduce. Therefore, a moderate support-metal interaction is beneficial for the catalytic activity in ammonia decomposition reaction [14]. Meanwhile the enhancement of the interaction between active metals and supports facilitates electron transfer, which plays a significant role in modulating the electronic structure of catalysts and improving catalytic performance. XPS analysis was employed to reveal the surface chemical states and electronic structures of the reduced Ni/CeO2 and Ni/M0.2Ce0.8Ox catalysts. Fig. 5 (a) presents the analysis of the Ni 2p region, indicating the presence of both Ni0 (∼852.1 eV) and Ni2+ (∼853.7 eV, ∼855.6 eV) on the surface. The presence of Ni2+ may be attributed to rapid oxidation during sample handling or absorption of trace moisture from the air, which is inevitable given that XPS is a surface-sensitive characterization technique. The incorporation of alkaline earth metals led to a trend of decreased binding energy for metallic Ni0. It is noteworthy that there is a regular correlation between the binding energy and the catalysis performance, with Ni/CeO2 > Ni/Mg0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Ca0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox. This suggests that the support provides additional electrons to the surface of the active metal, increasing the electron density around Ni0, which is favorable for the binding and desorption of nitrogen, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition. Fig. 5(b) analyzes the Ce 3d region, with the blue area corresponding to the 3d104f1 state of Ce3+ and the yellow area corresponding to the 3d10 state of Ce4+. The formation of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 is typically accompanied by the generation of Ce3+, hence the quantification of oxygen vacancies is achieved through the ratio Ce3+/ (Ce3+ + Ce4+), as shown in Table 1. The Ni/CeO2 catalyst has the highest number of oxygen vacancies, yet it exhibits the lowest ammonia decomposition conversion. Therefore, oxygen vacancies are not the only key factor contributing to the activity of the catalyst. 3.3 The kinetic analysis of catalysts 3.3.1 Kinetic parameters: activation energy and reaction order In order to better understand this promotion effect, we carried out kinetics measurements on these catalysts. The reaction rate can be expressed by a power law equation as follows: r = k ( p N H 3 ) a ( p H 2 ) b ( p N 2 ) c r is the reaction rate; k is the reaction rate constant; pi is the partial pressure of gas i, and a, b, and c are the reaction order for NH3, H2, and N2, respectively (c is usually 0 for N2). The rates were measured after eliminating both internal and external diffusion effects (WHSV=2460,000 mL·g-1·h-1, particle size 80–100 mesh) and the conversions were kept below 15 % to ensure differential kinetics region. The effects of NH3 and H2 partial pressures on the reaction rates are shown in Fig. 6 (a) and (b), respectively, and the measured reaction orders are shown in Table 2 . The rate was found to increase with increasing NH3 partial pressures, but decrease with increasing H2 partial pressures, indicating that the reaction is inhibited by the product hydrogen. The absolute value of the hydrogen reaction order: Ni/CeO2 > Ni/Mg0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Ca0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Sr0.2Ce0.8Ox > Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox, indicating that the addition of alkaline earth metals can significantly alleviate the hydrogen inhibition effect, consistent with the ammonia decomposition activity of the catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the calculated apparent activation energy based on the Arrhenius equation. Ni/Ba0.2Ce0.8Ox has the lowest reaction activation energy (Ea = 75 KJ·mol-1) under these conditions, corresponding to the highest ammonia decomposition conversion in the low temperature region in Fig. 1(a). 3.3.2 Kinetic modeling of Ni/CeO2: hydrogen inhibition Based on the kinetic measurements, kinetic models with and without the hydrogen inhibition effect have been developed for Ni/CeO2 using GT-SUITE software. For the Ni/CeO2 kinetic model, the model parameter values are all taken as experimental values. When hydrogen inhibition is not considered, the reaction rate equation is as follows: R = 10 6 * e − 88000 R T * { N H 3 } 0.53 Without considering hydrogen inhibition effect, the model simulation results show much higher ammonia conversion than the measured experimental values, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). However, after considering the hydrogen inhibition by adding the H2 inhibition amendment term G(i), the rate expression becomes: R ′ = R G ( i ) = 10 6 * e − 88000 R T * { N H 3 } 0.53 1 + A H 2 * e − E a , H 2 R T * { H 2 } 1.55 The choice of the hydrogen inhibition term ensures that the rate equation is not affected by hydrogen inhibition when {H2} = 0. The model result was found to agree well with the experimental result at varying temperatures and ammonia concentrations, as shown in Fig. 8(b). Hence the hydrogen inhibition phenomenon must be considered in the catalytic process of ammonia decomposition. To further validate the developed model, ammonia decomposition activity tests were performed under pure NH3 and 2885 ppm NH3 with the same flow rate of NH3 passed per unit of time, as shown in Fig. 9 . With 2885 ppm NH3, the ammonia decomposition conversion at 450 °C was found to be 58 % (blue curve), whereas the conversion drops to 9 % with pure NH3 (red curve), even though the space velocity is considerably lower. Due to the significant differences between the reaction conditions and the kinetic experimental conditions, the model is operated within a lower conversion range, which is primarily governed by kinetics. The model (displayed by the green and purple curves) accurately predicts the difference in conversion rates between the two conditions and underscores the pivotal role of the hydrogen inhibition effect. When pure ammonia serves as the reaction feed gas, the amount of H2 generated is significantly higher, leading to a substantial decrease in the ammonia decomposition conversion due to the hydrogen inhibition effect. 4 Conclusion The CeO2 catalysts modified with alkaline earth metals M (Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba) were synthesized via citric acid complexation, and their catalytic activities for ammonia decomposition were evaluated after the loading of Ni. Notably, the addition of alkaline earth metals, particularly Ba, was found to significantly enhance the ammonia conversion. Through meticulous characterization, it has been discovered that alkaline earth metals can enhance the basicity of catalysts. While the binding energy of metallic Ni0 exhibits a decreasing trend, indicating an enrichment of electrons around the active metal, thereby facilitating the recombination and desorption of nitrogen in ammonia decomposition reaction. Additionally, the introduction of alkaline earth metals destabilizes hydrogen on active sites, and the absolute value of the hydrogen reaction order also shows a gradually decreasing trend, suggesting that the inhibitory effect of hydrogen on ammonia decomposition reaction is significantly diminished. While a systematic kinetic study led to the development and validation of a kinetic model that accurately captures the hydrogen inhibition effect for the Ni/CeO2 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Ni-based catalysts, as non-noble metal alternatives, are widely regarded for their potential in ammonia decomposition for hydrogen production. However, their performance at low temperatures is suboptimal, necessitating the addition of promoters and a clear understanding of their mechanisms to enhance catalytic activity. In this study, we have successfully improved the low-temperature ammonia decomposition performance of Ni/CeO2 by incorporating alkaline earth metals and conducted a comprehensive analysis of the underlying structural and electronic effects. The findings reveal that alkaline earth metals can enhance the basicity of the catalyst and increase electron density around the active metal sites, thereby facilitating the rate-determining step of recombination and desorption of N atom. Moreover, the presence of alkaline earth metals disrupts hydrogen adsorption stability on the catalysts, effectively mitigating the impact of hydrogen inhibition. Based on systematic kinetic experiments, a kinetic model was developed that accurately captures the hydrogen inhibition effect for Ni/CeO2 catalysts. The insights into the promotional mechanisms of alkaline earth metals offer theoretical guidance for the development of highly active and cost-effective catalysts for ammonia decomposition.
coredata.dc:title: Promoting effect of alkaline earth metals on Ni/CeO2 catalysts for ammonia decomposition reaction
